awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: An Experimental Investigation of the Rheological Behavior and Seismic Anisotropy Signature of Deep Crustal Amphibole-Rich Rocks
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Cailey Condit has been granted an NSF EAR postdoctoral fellowship to carry out research and educational plans at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She will investigate the way amphibole, a common but poorly understood mineral within the earth's crust, behaves when it is deformed under high temperatures and pressures. This work will directly augment our understating of continuous deformation within ductile shear zones in the deep crust, where rocks flow rather than break, and within subduction zones, where oceanic crust is descending beneath continents. This experimental work is aimed at constraining the strength of these highly deformed, amphibole-rich zones and investigating their geophysical properties so that geophysicists can make more accurate inferences about amphibole-rich rocks from remote observations of the deep crust. By shedding new light on the strength and deformation behavior of amphibole, these data allow us to better predict how continuous deformation may influence the mechanics within zones of earthquake production. The education plan involves Dr. Condit (1) co-teaching a graduate-undergraduate seminar in rock deformation at MIT, (2) acting as a research mentor for several undergraduate researchers, (3) continuing and expanding her geologic outreach on social media, and (4) making geologic presentations at assisted living facilities to disseminate geologic knowledge across generations. 

Dr. Condit will utilize the state-of-the-art facilities at MIT's rock deformation laboratory to conduct a series of experiments on amphibole, deforming samples at a range of temperatures, pressures, and strain rates representative of those found in the middle to lower crust. With these experimental results, she will determine the deformation mechanisms of amphibole and its rheology under deep crustal conditions. She will then directly tie her observations of these experimentally deformed rocks to naturally deformed amphibole, and collect seismic anisotropy data from the experimentally deformed amphibole samples. This will allow for a direct comparison between deformation mechanism, rock strength, and seismic anisotropy signals produced by the deformed amphibole. These insights will allow geophysicists to better link their remotely sensed observations of seismic anisotropy with the amphibole-rich rocks that produce those signals in the deep crust. Geologists working on naturally deformed amphibole-rich rocks will also be able to use these data to constrain the strength and deformation mechanisms of their rocks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to provide experimental constraints on the way the mineral amphibole, a common mineral in the lower crust and upper mantle of the earth deforms during plate tectonic motion.  It is important to understand the way amphibole deforms and how strong it is during deformation because it is a common mineral found in ductily deformed fault zones and based on geologic work, the way it deforms may control the overall strength of the crust at these deeper depths (~20-60 km below the surface). However, because we cannot observe amphibole deforming in the deep crust right now because it is too hot and deep to recover any of these rocks, we need to devise an alternative method to study the strength of this important mineral. Thus, we preformed deformation experiments at the MIT Rock Deformation Laboratory at temperatures and pressures that amphibole feels in the deep crust.

            The aims of these experiments were to (1) quantify the absolute strength of amphibole as it deforms at deep crustal pressures and temperatures and (2) to examine exactly how amphibole is deforming at these conditions. This work’s intellectual merit is that with these two pieces of information, geologists will be able to estimate the strength of currently deforming deep crust that is rich in amphibole. Geoscientists will also be able to link observations of amphibole from the geologic record to deformation in the deep crust. Ultimately, this will allow geoscientists a more complete understanding of how deformation occurs during plate tectonics.

            Over 15 experiments were done at temperatures ranging from 700-850°C and pressures of 1500 MPa (equivalent to conditions at ~50 km deep in the earth) in a specialized high pressure-temperature deformation rig. Each experiment took about a week to set up and up to four days to run. The results of these experiments were (1) amphibole can be quite weak in the deep crust, with a strength less than other common minerals like feldspar and (2) amphibole deforms by a crystal plastic deformation mechanism called dislocation creep. Geoscientists can now use the quantitative constraints from our experiments to calculate the strength of amphibole rich rocks in the deep crust and look at the way amphibole deformed and match it to our experimental deformation style. This represents a significant advancement in our understanding of the strength of the deep crust.

            The broader impacts of this work were to provide mentorship and opportunities to an undergraduate scientist from an underrepresented group in the geosciences. A undergraduate researcher was hosted at MIT by the PI from the Research Experience in Solid Earth Science for Students (RESESS) program run by UNAVCO in Boulder, CO. This undergraduate was hosted at MIT summer 2019, where she conducted research on the seismic anisotropy (the directional dependance of the speed of seismic waves) on these deformed amphiboles so that we can link our experimental results to geophysical remote observations. This undergraduate researcher presented her summer project at a national research conference fall 2019. She also used this research as a seed for a prestigious NSF Graduate Research Fellowship application which she was awarded. The PI wrote letters of recommendation for this undergraduate researcher and has acted as a longer term mentor since summer 2019. Overall, this project provided an invaluable experience for this undergraduate researcher who is now getting a PhD in Geophysics at the University of Colorado.

            The outcomes of this award include (1) new experimental constraints on the strength of amphibole during deep crustal tectonic deformation, (2) improved understanding of the way amphibole deforms during deep crustal tectonic activity, (3) mentorship of an undergraduate researcher at MIT from an underrepresented group in the geosciences, and (4) invited talks for the PI on this research at two separate national conferences which disseminates this research to the broader scientific community.
